Description: Body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Corinthian black-figured pottery open vessel, probably a column-krater; interior: glazed black (fired brown); exterior: black-figure decoration consisting possibly of deer (only shoulders and horns remaining), grazing to left; motif to the left unclear, probably animal with reversed head.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 114, no. A190, pl. LXXX)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.002) (Phase 1)
